svg.style: background: transparent; background-color: transparent; color-scheme: light dark;

ellipse.style: fill: light-dark(#ffffff, var(--ge-dark-color, #121212)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

path.style: stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); animation: 500ms linear 0s infinite normal none running ge-flow-animation-qNGOP01AnwUpq5r1LGDw; stroke-dashoffset: 16;
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000; background-color: #ffffff;

div.p: 1. ARP's primary purpose is to map an IP address to a MAC address so that ethernet frame can be delivered at the physical layer on a LAN

switch.text: 1. ARP's primary purpose is to map an IP address to a MAC ad...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 360px; height: 1px; padding-top: 180px; margin-left: 316px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 56px; overflow: hidden; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

font.span: It never reaches remote networks. So it only keeps the cache of IP addresses part of it's local subnet (LAN)

switch.text: 2. ARP is a LAN-only protocol. It never crosses routers.It n...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 360px; height: 1px; padding-top: 240px; margin-left: 316px;

p.span: 3. If the destination IP is on the same subnet, ARP resolves its MAC, otherwise ARP resolves the defualt gateway's (router's IP) MAC

div.p: 1. Device A,will creates an ARP packet: "Who has IP 192.168.1.20? Tell Target IP 192.168.1.10."

switch.text: 1. Device A,will creates an ARP packe...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 220px; height: 1px; padding-top: 995px; margin-left: 286px;

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.p: 2. Encapsulates it in an Ethernet frame: Source MAC = A's MAC; Destination MAC = Broadcast (FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF—all 1s, floods the LAN).

p.font: ARP requests are 28-byte payloads inside an Ethernet frame (64 bytes total)

switch.text: 2. Encapsulates it in an Ethernet fra...

div.p:
"IP 192.168.1.20 is at MAC 77:88:99:AA:BB:CC."
(Source: B's IP/MAC; Target: A's IP/MAC—no broadcast here for efficiency.)

p.span: to see which one has Target IP

div.p: 1. On each device, every network interface(including router) receives it too, Because destination MAC address is set to FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF (the universal "everyone address")

p.font: 2. device cannot ignore them because broadcast frames are addressed to FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF, which all NICs are designed to accept.
